Topic.Title: Charlie Munger has it right but the SEC won't listen nor the FED!

Message.Msg: I know, I know..... all those "bound for sainthood" Banksters were just doing God's work. They were all forced by the Democrat party to take advantage of the fraudulent, the stupid and the poor! Remember there would be no sub-prime mortgages if the Banksters would not have cleverly buried the #$%$ into the CDO tranches. The next piece of the swindle was the CDO's were so convoluted that even sophisticated buyers in the debt markets were caught with their pants down! Caveat emptor would normally be the watch word but you had the Banksters in cahoots with the rating agencies which further complicated reality! Best example of fraudulent financial engineering in the history of money!

Topic.Title: GUTLESS LIAR TEA BAGGER TURDS FLUSHED AND SPIRALING DOWN
Charlie Munger has it right but the SEC won't listen nor the FED!

Message.Msg: You've got a selective collection of facts and zero comprehension of motivation. It's twisted, really. If you were there, perhaps one could take you seriously. But no, you're just repeating propaganda, and you weren't there, and you don't know. Your statement about subprime is evidence of your lack of knowledge. Read some history, and not the revisionist kind written by Obama and his ilk trying to escape blame for what they caused. Sophisticated buyers not only demanded those components, they in fact designed them. When they blew up, they made lots of claims of victimhood that have so far fallen on deaf ears in the courts, and with very good reason given the perfectly documented complicity of the supposed victims. Any settlements to date on that specific topic are tiny and more about avoidance of legal costs (which every plaintiff plays to) versus an admition or proof of any guilt. It's hard to take your comments seriously when they are full of unfounded supposition and regurgitation of false propaganda.

Topic.Title: Charlie Munger has it right but the SEC won't listen nor the FED!

Message.Msg: The corruption you refer to was a by-product of regulation that encouraged it. No memory loss on my side, and I am not saying that there aren't some subtle truths buried in your original & subsequent posts. The problem is that the false aspects buried the true elements. Were you to have said that the govt regulation which enjoined the banks from making only prudent loans encouraged an environment of greed and corruption, then you would have been far more accurate. To the point, the aftermath has demonstrated there were incredibly sloppy/fraudulent drive-by CDO/MBS rating processes, horribly inaccurate/fraudulent appraisals, 5 minute apps with lots of blanks, and the credit policy lessons of thousands of years were thrown out the window on account of the supposed wisdom of the Fair Isaac credit scoring model (fico), where fico-only loans would actually be rejected if there was any documentation in the loan package of ability to repay (other than fico). It doesn't take much imagination to see why this model turned out to be utterly worthless since the product was predicated on the fundamentally incorrect assumption an ever-rising market, and the asset value turned out to be highly volatile toward the negative. These products and others like them were not decisions of the banks alone, but decisions made cooperatively between the banks, the GSEs (Fannie/Freddie), the secondary markets packagers who didn't even originate loans, and the private party buyers of the MBS packages.

Then immigration, with demint calling immigration bill a massive drain on USA treasury, but speaking for lawful immigration. Senate bill permits a detrimental drain upon USA treasury. Then Warren Buffett, speaking before his firm’s annual meeting. 1) usa economy improved past four plus years, thus giving some credit to g w bush. 2) He anticipates 2014 primaries to be unusually important 3) Let USA use all its talent—he was especially citing talent of women. Matalin, touching upon 2 amendment ad guns, etc, stressed no 2013 congressional proposals would have changed Newtown. Sen Ayotte told that to daughter of Newton principal. Jason Collins—his “coming out” revealed USA is ready to accepts gays “coming out’ in professional sports. Topic.Title: Guantanamo burns through $900,000 a year per inmate

Message.Msg: Well I tried to post a link from the Miami Herald for 2011 budget which was slightly lower, but yahoo doesn't like link posts and deleted the whole thing. In the article, there's a link to their FOIA request, which they summarized into 4 categories. Detainment camp operations was $30 million. The other figures that made up the whole of $138.8MM in 2011 would have been spent regardless of where the prisoners are housed. Based on the increase into 2012, that number would have gone up to maybe $35 million. If you can find the link to the main story, you can click on the fiscal 2011 link and get the actual breakdown, and you will find that the propagandists have been quite busy selling a partially true, but mostly false, narrative.

Message.Title: Miami Hearld on Gitmo expenses
Message.Msg: "The Defense Department “spends approximately $150 million per year on detention operations at Guantánamo, currently at a rate of more than $800,000 per detainee,” Attorney General Eric Holder and Defense Secretary Leon Panetta and other Cabinet members wrote Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell and others. “Meanwhile, our federal prisons spend a little over $25,000 per year, per prisoner, and federal courts and prosecutors routinely handle numerous terrorist case a year well within their operating budgets.” The Herald then sought to do a line-by-line analysis of the expenses, with which the secretive prison camp command refused to participate. It instructed The Miami Herald to file a Freedom of Information Act request, which Southcom refused to expedite in consideration of the ongoing budget debate." 5/5/13
